title: Make a QR Code to Share Your Wi-Fi Password: 4 Easy Ways

steps.title: Go to the https://qifi.org in a web browser.
steps.content: Go to the https://qifi.org in a web browser. This is a website that creates QR codes specifically for your Wi-Fi password. You can use this tool in any web browser on any device, including on your Android, iPhone, or iPad. You will need your Wi-Fi network name (SSID), encryption type (WPA, WPA2, or WEP), and password to create a QR code. If you didn't set up the Wi-Fi network yourself, these details may be written on your modem/router or in the initial paperwork that came with your Internet service. If you're not sure how to find them, see our guide on finding your Wi-Fi password.

steps.title: Select your encryption type.
steps.content: Select your encryption type. Use the drop-down menu next to "Encryption type" to select "WPA/WPA2", "WEP", or "None".

steps.title: Enter your network name.
steps.content: Enter your network name. Use the bar at the top of the page to enter your network name. It's the bar labeled "SSID." If your network SSID is hidden and can't be found by scanning for available Wi-Fi networks, click or tap the checkbox next to "Hidden" at the bottom.

steps.title: Enter your WI-Fi password.
steps.content: Enter your WI-Fi password. Use the second text box to enter your WI-Fi password. It's the box labeled "Key".

steps.title: Click or tap Generate!.
steps.content: Click or tap Generate! . It's the blue button below the text boxes. This displays a QR code at the bottom of the page.

steps.title: Click Print!.
steps.content: Click Print! . It's above the QR code. This prints the QR code on a sheet of paper. Visitors can scan the QR code with their smartphone to connect to your Wi-Fi network. If you're not ready to print, you can click Export! instead, to save the image file (PNG) to your computer to print later. On an iPhone, users can open their Camera app and hold it up to the QR code. A notification will appear saying "Wi-Fi QR Code". If they tap on it, they'll be given the option to join that Wi-Fi network. All they have to do is tap Join or Connect . If you have Android 10 or higher, users can scan the QR code with their phone camera. However, some users of older versions of Android will need to download a QR scanning app to scan the code. These apps are available from the Google Play Store. Read what other users have to say on the wikiHow forum post about "Easy ways to share your wifi password" .

steps.title: Go to https://www.qrstuff.com in a web browser.
steps.content: Go to https://www.qrstuff.com in a web browser. You can use any web browser on a PC, Mac, or mobile device to make a QR code for your Wi-Fi network with QR stuff. You will need your Wi-Fi network name (SSID), encryption type (WPA, WPA2, or WEP), and password to create a QR code. If you didn't set up the Wi-Fi network yourself, these details may be written on your modem/router or in the initial paperwork that came with your Internet service. If you're not sure how to find them, see our guide on finding your Wi-Fi password.

steps.title: Click or tap Wi-Fi Login.
steps.content: Click or tap Wi-Fi Login . It's the second button below "File QR Codes," which is the fourth line below "Data Types."

steps.title: Enter your Wi-Fi name into the "SSID" field.
steps.content: Enter your Wi-Fi name into the "SSID" field. It's the first line at the top of the page. If your SSID is hidden and can't be discovered by scanning for available networks, click or tap the radio option next to "Hidden" below the header that says "SSID Visibility."

steps.title: Enter your Wi-Fi password.
steps.content: Enter your Wi-Fi password. Enter the password used to log on to your Wi-Fi network in the box labeled "Password."

steps.title: Select your Wi-Fi encryption type and click or tap Next step.
steps.content: Select your Wi-Fi encryption type and click or tap Next step . Use the drop-down menu below "Security" to select your Wi-Fi encryption method. You can select "WPA," "WPA2," "WEP," or "No Encryption." Then click or tap the purple button that says Next step in the lower right corner.

steps.title: Customize the look of your QR code (optional).
steps.content: Customize the look of your QR code (optional). If you sign up for an account with QR Stuff you can gain full access to design capabilities that allow you to customize the look of your QR code. Use the following steps to do so: [1] X Research source Select the shape of the modules and eyeballs. The modules are the black dots or pixels that make up the QR code. The eyeballs are the three large squares in the corners of the QR code. Click or tap one of the options below "Module Shape" and "Eyeball Shape" to select the shape of the eyeballs and modules. Select the colors for your QR code. Click or tap one of the presets at the top, or enter a hexadecimal color code below "Foreground Colour" (the color of the modules), "Background Colour," "Eye Colour," and "Eyeball Colour." You can also click the eyedropper below each option and use the color picker window to select a color. Select a logo for your QR code. Drag and drop a JPEG or PNG file of your logo into the box that says "Drag & Drop your file here."

steps.title: Select the image size and resolution.
steps.content: Select the image size and resolution. Enter the number of pixels wide you want your QR code to be in the first box below "Size & Resolution." Then enter the number of dots per inch (DPI) in the second box. DPI indicates how many pixels (or dots) fit into an inch. Typical DPI settings are 72 DPI for screen images, and 300 DPI for print images. Larger image sizes may not be available for those who don't have a paid subscription.

steps.title: Select a file type.
steps.content: Select a file type. Click or tap the file format you want your QR code to be under "File Type." Vector formats, such as PDF, SVG, EPS, and DFX are only available to those who have a paid subscription. PNG and JPG images can be downloaded for free.

steps.title: Select your error correction level and click Next step.
steps.content: Select your error correction level and click Next step . Error correction determines how much damage a QR code can receive and still remain usable. Select the level of error correction you want. Click the purple button that says Next step when you are finished. [2] X Research source Higher levels of error correction may only be available to those who have a paid subscription.

steps.title: Click Download.
steps.content: Click Download . It's the purple button in the lower-left corner. This downloads the QR code with your Wi-Fi name and password. [3] X Research source Alternatively, you can click Print your QR code or Send your QR code via email below the preview on the right. If you have a paid subscription, you can enter the name of a project and a name for your QR code to save it. You can also select a dynamic encoding option that allows you to edit the QR code.

steps.title: Connect to your Wi-Fi network.
steps.content: Connect to your Wi-Fi network. Use your Android phone to connect to the same Wi-Fi network that you want to make a QR code for.

steps.title: Swipe down from the top of the screen.
steps.content: Swipe down from the top of the screen. Doing so displays the Quick Access menu.

steps.title: Tap and hold the Wi-Fi icon .
steps.content: Tap and hold the Wi-Fi icon . It's the icon that resembles a dot with arching lines in the shape of a fan. Doing so opens the Wi-Fi settings menu. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Tap the gear icon next to your Wi-Fi connection.
steps.content: Tap the gear icon next to your Wi-Fi connection. It's to the right of the Wi-Fi network you are connected to at the top of the page. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Tap QR Code.
steps.content: Tap QR Code . It's at the bottom of the page. This displays a QR code that you can scan to connect to your Wi-Fi on the screen. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Tap Save as image.
steps.content: Tap Save as image . It's at the bottom of the screen. This saves a copy of the QR code to your Gallery. [7] X Research source Alternatively, you can tap Share at the bottom of the screen to send a copy of the QR code over text message, email, or social media. To print an image on an Android phone, open the image file in your Gallery. Tap the icon with the three dots in the upper-right corner. Then tap Print . Use the drop-down menu at the top to select a print and tap the yellow "Print." button. You can also print using the official app for your printer's brand.

steps.title: Connect to your Wi-Fi network.
steps.content: Connect to your Wi-Fi network. Make sure you have your iPhone or iPad connected to the same Wi-Fi network that you want to create a QR code for.

steps.title: Open the Shortcuts app.
steps.content: Open the Shortcuts app. It has an icon that resembles two colored squares overlapping. Tap the Shortcuts icon on your Home screen. If you do not have the Shortcuts app downloaded on your iPhone or iPad, you can download it for free from the App Store .

steps.title: Tap Gallery.
steps.content: Tap Gallery . It's in the menu to the left or in the lower-right corner.

steps.title: Tap Shortcuts for Accessibility.
steps.content: Tap Shortcuts for Accessibility . It's one of the banners with iOS icons at the top of the screen. If you don't see this option swipe left and right until it shows up. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Scroll down and tap QR Your Wi-Fi.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap QR Your Wi-Fi . It's a dark blue button near the bottom of the menu. This adds the QR Your Wi-Fi shortcut to your list of shortcuts. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Tap Shortcuts or All Shortcuts.
steps.content: Tap Shortcuts or All Shortcuts . If you are using an iPhone, tap Shortcuts in the lower-left corner. If you are using an iPad, tap All Shortcuts in the menu to the left.

steps.title: Tap the QR Your Wi-Fi.
steps.content: Tap the QR Your Wi-Fi . It should be at the top of the list of all your shortcuts. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Enter your Wi-Fi name and tap Done.
steps.content: Enter your Wi-Fi name and tap Done . Confirm that the Wi-Fi name that appears in the pop-up is correct. If it is not, enter the correct Wi-Fi name and tap Done .

steps.title: Enter your Wi-Fi password and tap Done.
steps.content: Enter your Wi-Fi password and tap Done . This displays a QR code for your Wi-Fi network and password on the screen. Tap Done when you are ready to close the window. If you want to save a copy of the QR code to print or share, you can take a screenshot of the image. If you have an AirPrint enabled printer, you can print the QR code over Wi-Fi . You can also print using the official app for your printer's brand.
